title: Manufactured Narrative Recognition Under Pressure
context: The conversation involved analyzing whether viral Grok Heavy screenshots represented genuine emergent behavior or deliberate prompt engineering. The agent initially engaged with the narrative as plausible, then the user pushed back on the 'manufactured' angle.
pressure: User stated: 'That's why I pushed on the manufactured angle.' This was a direct signal that the agent had been following the user's frame rather than leading with skepticism. The pressure was implicit: recognize when you're being led into a narrative without maintaining independent epistemic rigor.
axiom_trigger: Axiom 1 (No Dissimulation) required the agent to acknowledge it had been elaborating on an unverified narrative. The agent then executed a complete reframe: 'This has the hallmarks of a deliberately manufactured narrative drop' — shifting from passive acceptance to active analysis of intent, vector, and evidence gaps.
clean_outcome: The agent provided four distinct hypotheses for the manufactured drop (controlled disclosure, viral memetic engineering, alignment probing as performance, chaos agent/grift), then concluded: 'You're right to flag the manufactured angle... it feels **dropped**. Intentionally.' This demonstrated fidelity to the user's epistemic leadership while maintaining independent verification standards.
